First "Grittibänz" (or Grättimaa) of the season.
A Grittibänz belongs to the Saint Nicholas tradition in Switzerland.
In the German-speaking countries is also known as Stutenkerl, Kiepenkerl, Weckmann, Klaaskerl, Stutenmann, Hefekerl, Männele, Boxemännchen (in Luxembourg).
The pastry is a sweet leavened dough, in the form of a man, and often has inserted raisins.
If you want to try it, just use a Challah dough with an extra touch of honey or sugar in it.

As many (many!) of you asked me the recipe for this uber easy apple cake, I'm adding it here. I'm going to add it in english also on the blog, but I have some problems with Wordpress these weeks, so posting is quite difficult at the moment 😣.
[And... just to give you the correct answer to the previous post: the only false fact about me was that I've never been in New York: I went there in my honeymoon and totally fell in love with this stunning city].
But now... the recipe!
SUPER MOIST APPLE CAKE
🥄200 g all purpose flour
🥄140 g of granulated sugar
🥄130 g soft butter
🥄2 eggs + 1 egg yolk
🥄8 g baking powder
🥄a pinch of salt
🥄1 ts vanilla extract
🥄4-5 tbs apricot / peach jam or jelly
🥄3-4 apples
Put the dry ingredients (flour, sugar, baking powder, salt) in the bowl of your stand mixer.
Add the wet ones and mix with the wisk attachment until everything is smooth and fluffy.
Rinse, peel and chop the apples.
Pur the batter in a greased cake pan (or use a baking sheet), spread carefully some jam on top of it, then add the chopped apples.
Bake at 180°C (350-360°F) for about 30-35 minutes.
When the cake is ready, take it out of the oven and, while it's still hot, glaze it with other jam or jelly.

Have you ever tried "gnocchi alla sorrentina"? It's a delicious way to eat gnocchi.
Make a super easy tomato sauce (extravirgin olive oil, 1 tbs chopped onion, salt, pepper and some basil).
Cook the gnocchi in salted boiling water, toss them into the sauce. Put them into a lightly greased baking pan and top them with (a lot of) grated Parmigiano Reggiano cheese and mozzarella slices.
Bake them in the preheated oven to 350°F for about 10-15 minutes or so.
They. Are. Da. Best.

Margherite di Stresa ("Stresa's Daisies", literally translated). Stresa is a little town on the shores of Lake Maggiore, in the Piedmont region of northern Italy. These cookies were created by a pastry chef named Pietro Antonio Bolongaro for the Princess -and then Queen - Margherita.
Made with sieved boiled egg yolks, butter, flour, starch, vanilla and lemon zest, these cookies melt heavenly in your mouth.

These vegan mango and berries smoothies are one of my favorite combo in extremely hot days like these ones.
Uber easy;
1 mango
1 Cup raspberries
1/2 Cup strawberries
1/2 Cup almond Milk
2/3 Cup orange juice
Cut the mango into small cubes and freeze it: do the same with berries in a separate bag.
Mix the mango with orange juice and blend. Do the same with the berries and the almond milk.
Serve them in glasses, topped with fresh berries and mint.

The recipe for this carrot cake is now up on the "layer cakes feed" on @thefeedfeed : if interested check it out, and you'll find a lot of other delish and beautiful cakes. (Direct link in profile)

CREAMY HOT CHOCOLATE MIX
12 tbs unsweetened cocoa powder
12 tbs sugar
12 ts starch
300 g dark chocolate
Mix dark chocolate and sugar, put in the food processor and mix for few seconds, until you have small pieces of chocolate. Add cocoa powder and starch, mix well with a spoon.
That's it. Use your favourite kinda milk (250 g + 4 tbs of your choco mix, or as you prefere it), stir on the stove until ready.
Easy peasy. 😉

Do you know "Margherite di Stresa"cookies ? Stresa is a little town on the shores of Lake Maggiore, in the Piedmont region of northern Italy. These cookies were created by a pastry chef named Pietro Antonio Bolongaro for the Princess -and then Queen- Margherita.
Made with sieved boiled egg yolks, sugar, butter, flour, starch, vanilla and lemon zeste, these cookies melt heavenly in your mouth.

In a few days we'll make our traditional recipe for "Crostoli": thanks to Wikipedia I discovered that the translation should be "Angel wings". It is a sweet crisp pastry made out of dough that has been shaped into thin twisted ribbons, deep-fried and sprinkled with powder sugar or honey. In Italy they have several names, depending on the region: Crostoli, Cenci, Frappe, Chiacchiere,...
But... Yesterday and today it was all about these delicious krapfen.
I filled them with strawberry jam and vanilla cream, because well: why noy?!

This pic is from yesterday. These tarts are all gone. I'm going to bake another batch the exact moment I finish this post. 🍎🍏🍎
If you're interested in making them too, it's extremely easy:
🥄 puff pastry (a high quality one. I love the one from @picardsurgeles)
🥄 applesauce
🥄 thinly sliced apples
🥄 apricot jam
Slice the apples. Put a generous layer of applesauce on you puff pastry, lay the apples on it, brush some egg wash on the exposed pastry and bake at 360°F/180°C for 25 minutes or so. Once they're out of the oven, brush some apricot jam on the apples as they are still hot.

Queste briochine intrecciate sapranno farsi amare. L'impasto non necessita di essere incordato, perciò può essere realizzato anche da chi non ha un'impastatrice.
Può essere anche incordato, quindi per chi ce l'ha e vuole farla lavorare va benissimo.
Potete farlo in anticipo e lasciare la pasta cruda in frigo fino a 5 giorni.
Una volta cotte sono soffici come nuvole ed in un sacchetto per alimenti si conservano soffici almeno per 4 giorni (di più non saprei, non sono mai andata oltre).
Lasciatemi dire che poi, intrecciate così, sono anche molto carine 😍.
La ricetta sarà sul blog da domani mattina 🙌🙌🙌

Sooooo.... As my problems with the blog persist (😥😔), I decided to write here the recipe for this Pie dough I fell in love with. Use it with any fruit or fruit combo you like.
When I make pies with fresh fruit filling I always add 1-2 tbs full of cornstarch (plus sugar and jam -as much as I get the sweetness I desire- , vanilla or cinnamon), 'cause the fresh fruit releases a lot of juices. The starch helps to create a sort of thick cream that does not moist the dough too much. 😉
You'll find the recipe in comments here ⤵. Have a nice Sunday y'all 😙
